Effects of temperature and time on the facile low-temperature pre-sulfurization of tube-like unsupported Co-Mo catalysts for hydrodesulfurization Zhengting Xiao Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft Visualization a b Qingyang Li Investigation b Wentai Wang Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ Guangci Li Conceptualization Methodology Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition b ⁎ Guannan Lin Investigation b Xuebing Li Supervision b Song Chen Formal analysis b a Key Laboratory of Marine Chemistry Theory and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Ocean University of China, No. 238 Songling Road, Laoshan District, Qingdao 266100, PR China Key Laboratory of Marine Chemistry Theory and Technology Ministry of Education College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Ocean University of China No. 238 Songling Road, Laoshan District Qingdao 266100 PR China aKey Laboratory of Marine Chemistry Theory and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Ocean University of China, No. 238 Songling Road, Laoshan District, Qingdao 266100, PR China b Key Laboratory of Biofuels, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.189 Songling Road, Laoshan District, Qingdao 266101, PR China Key Laboratory of Biofuels Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology Chinese Academy of Sciences No.189 Songling Road, Laoshan District Qingdao 266101 PR China bKey Laboratory of Biofuels, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.189 Songling Road, Laoshan District, Qingdao 266101, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A Co-Mo sulfide catalyst with tube-like structure was prepared through a low-temperature pre-sulfurization process using rod-like CoMoO4 as the precursor. The pre-sulfurization temperature greatly affected the total pore volume, the concentration of CoMoS species, the microstructure of (Co)MoS2 slabs and the catalytic desulfurization activity. The increased temperature can promote the formation of hollow structure and the sulfurization degree of the precursor. It was found that the excessive temperature induced the Co atoms to form more isolated Co9S8 species, hindering the formation of highly active CoMoS species. Therefore, appropriate temperature is more favorable to form the (Co)MoS2 slabs with shorter length and higher stacking number, leading to more coordinatively unsaturated sites, especially the corner sites. According to the results of hydrodesulfurization reaction, the reaction rate of dibenzothiophene and the yields of liquid products are highly depended on the number of surface-active sites, which are mainly originated from the Type II CoMoS species. Moreover, the extended pre-sulfurization time can further improve the catalytic desulfurization activity of the catalyst at an appropriate pre-sulfurization temperature. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrodesulfurization Dibenzothiophene Co-Mo sulfides Low-temperature pre-sulfurization Hollow structure Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the increase of environmental pollution from vehicle tail gas, the sulfur content in transportation fuels is greatly restricted. Hence, the development of efficient desulfurization technology has become one of the hot topics in the field of fuels. The hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and non-hydrodesulfurization (non-HDS) are the two main desulfurization technologies at present. The non-HDS technologies include the traditional acid-base refining, solvent extraction, chemical deposition and adsorption desulfurization [1,2]. However, some unsolved problems remain on the non-HDS technologies, which limit their broad application. The HDS are the commonly used technologies in the industry as their high desulfurization efficiency and good economy. The preparation of HDS catalysts is the key factor. Currently, the transition-metal (Co, Mo, Ni, W) sulfide supported on active alumina and SiO2 are commonly used HDS catalysts [3–5]. As the contents of active components in the supported catalysts are limited, the sulfur content in the fuel cannot be reduced to the desired level under normal reaction conditions. Meanwhile, the structure of the active components will be affected by the metal-support interaction, leading to the reduction of the desulfurization activity, because most of the components are existed in the form of single phase (i.e., Co9S8 and MoS2) instead of highly active Co-Mo-S phase [6]. On the contrary, the unsupported catalysts are not restricted by the support, therefore, the content of active components are greatly increased, leading to higher activity [7–9]. Soled et al. reported an unsupported trimetallic Ni-Mo-W catalyst with higher HDS activity of at least three times than conventional supported CoMo/γ-Al2O3 and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts [10,11]. Although the unsupported catalysts show satisfactory catalytic activity, some shortcomings still remain, such as low dispersion and utilization of active metal. Hence, many efforts have been done to increase the quantity of effective active metals. Genuit et al. prepared a series of Ni(Co)-Mo sulfide catalysts through simple co-precipitation in the presence of nonionic surfactants, followed by pre-sulfurization with H2S/H2 mixture at atmospheric pressure. The higher specific surface area of the catalysts leaded to the high HDS activity of thiophene and 4,6-DMDBT [12]. Li et al. [13] reported an unsupported rod-shaped Co-Mo sulfide catalyst with good HDS reaction activity and selectivity due to the improved the dispersion of Mo species in Co-Mo oxides prepared by ion-exchange method. Sollner et al. [14] synthesized unsupported Co-Mo sulfide catalysts with comparable HDS activity to the catalysts reported in literatures, using sulfur as pre-sulfurization agent instead of H2S. Although these new methods can improve the dispersion of active metal in the unsupported catalysts, their utilization is still lower than that of supported catalysts, because most of the metal atoms are restricted inside the particles which are inaccessible during the catalytic reactions. Our previous work found that CoMoO4 particles can be sulfurized to form active Co-Mo sulfide using ethanol solution of CS2 as sulfurization agent under mild conditions [15]. The rod-like oxide particles were transformed to tube-like sulfide during the pre-sulfurization process, which increased the exposure of active components and the number of accessible active sites, leading to a higher catalytic desulfurization capacity. Moreover, the pre-sulfurization process plays a key role in the formation of hollow structure, but the effects of the pre-sulfurization conditions on the microstructure and activity of the catalyst are still not clear. Herein, a series of Co-Mo sulfides were prepared at different pre-sulfurization temperatures. The effects of temperature on the crystalline structure, morphology, microstructure, and composition and desulfurization activity were investigated, respectively. It was found that moderate pre-sulfurization temperature was favorable to obtain the catalyst with larger pore volume and higher exposure degree of active species, resulting in higher catalytic activity. In addition, prolonging pre-sulfurization time can also improve the catalytic activity at a certain temperature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation All chemicals are AR standard grade and used as received without further purification. Ammonium molybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O), absolute ethanol (C2H5OH), carbon disulfide (CS2) and decalin (C10H18) were purchased from Sinopharm. Cobalt acetate (Co(CH3COO)2∙4H2O) and dibenzothiophene (C12H8S) were purchased from Aladdin. 2.2 Co-Mo precursor preparation The precursors were prepared via a co-precipitation process without any acid or alkaline precipitant. Typically, a certain amount of cobalt acetate (4.0 mmol) and ammonium molybdate (0.57 mmol) were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water to form a clear solution, followed by adding 100 mL of absolute ethanol. The resultant mixed solution was transferred into an oil bath and refluxed at 80 °C for 4 h to form a purple precipitate. Finally, the precipitate was filtered, washed with deionized water for several times, and dried in air at 80 °C overnight. 2.2.1 Co-Mo sulfide catalyst preparation The Co-Mo sulfide catalysts were prepared through a facile pre-sulfurization process at low temperature. Typically, 0.4 g of the as-prepared precursor was put into a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave with mechanical stirring, followed by adding 30.0 g of sulfurizing agent (an ethanol solution containing 2.0 wt.% carbon disulfide). Prior to each experiment, the reactor was purged with H2 for three times to replace the air inside. Then the precursor was sulfurized in 2.0 MPa H2 (initial pressure at room temperature) at 120 °C (140 °C, 160 °C, 180 °C) for 6 h with a stirring rate of 600 r/min. After that, the sulfide was collected by filtration, washed with ethanol for three times, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 8 h. The obtained Co-Mo sulfide was then activated by 10 vol.% H2/Ar with a flow rate of 80 mL/min at 350 °C for 4 h in a tube furnace. After being activated, the sulfide was passivated in 0.5 vol.% O2/He for 30 min at room temperature. The obtained Co-Mo sulfide catalysts were named as Cat-120, Cat-140, Cat-160 and Cat-180, according to the different sulfurization temperatures. 2.3 Materials characterization The crystalline phases of the precursors and sulfides were characterized by X-ray diffractionon a Brucker AXS-D8 Advance powder diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ= 1.5406 Å), voltage of 40 kV and a current of 40 mA, and 2θ ranges between 5° and 60°. Textural properties were determined by N2adsorption-desorptiononMicromeritics ASAP 2020 apparatus. The specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the pore volumes and pore size were determined by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method from desorption branch of the isotherms. The microscopy analyses were conducted by scanning electron microscope (SEM, FEI Quanta200) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEM-2100). The chemical structure of composites was analyzed by X-ray photoelectronic spectroscopy (XPS) on Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with a monochromatic X-ray source of Al Kα under ultra-high vacuum (3.2 × 10−6 Pa) and a hemispherical analyzer. The Gaussian-Lorentzian functions and non-linear squares fitting algorithm were applied in the peak fitting. The C 1s peak (from adventitious carbon) at 284.6 eV was used as reference. Binding energies were reproducible within ±0.2 eV. The composition of surface elements was determined by fitting and integrating the Co 2p, Mo 3d, S 2p, C 1s and O 1s bands and converting these values to atomic ratios using theoretical sensitivity factors provided by the manufacturer of the XPS apparatus. Gandubert et al. proposed a method for analyzing CoMoS spectra [16,17]: (1) C ( i ) T = A i / S i ∑ i = L . . . . n A i / S i × 100 (2) C C o M o S = D C o M o S × C ( C o ) T where Ai is the measured area of species i, Si is the sensitivity factor of the atom related to species i (provided by the manufacturer), C(i)T is the absolute content of species i, CCoMoS is the absolute content of CoMoS species, DCoMoS is the distribution of Co. In order to investigate the relationship between morphology of (Co)MoS2 phase and hydrodesulfurization activity, at least ten representative HRTEM images were captured from different parts of each catalyst. The average slab length (L A) and stacking number (N A) of (Co)MoS2 slabs over the catalyst were measured based on at least 200 slabs for each catalyst. The (Co)MoS2 slabs are assumed to be perfect hexagonal, therefore, the related morphology parameters of the (Co)MoS2 slabs can be calculated as follows [18]: (3) L A = ∑ l i n where LA is the average slab length of (Co)MoS2 slabs (nm), n is the total number of slabs, and li is the length of slab i (nm). (4) N A = ∑ n i N i n where NA is the average stacking number of (Co)MoS2 slabs, ni is the number of stacks with Ni layers. (5) n ′ i = 10 × L ¯ / 3.2 + 1 2 (6) f e = 6 n i ′ − 12 3 n i ′ 2 − 3 n i ′ + 1 (7) f c = 6 3 n i ′ 2 − 3 n i ′ + 1 where n i ′ is the number of Mo atoms along one side of a (Co)MoS2 slab, f e is the fraction of Mo atoms at the edge sites, f c is the fraction of Mo atoms at the corner sites. NO-TPD experiment was carried out to determine the coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUSs) of sulfide catalysts. The quality of the samples used in each test remains basically the same. Prior to each test, the catalyst was pretreated at 350 °C in H2 atmosphere for 1 h to remove impurities. After cooling to 50 °C, a mixture of 10 vol.% NO/He was introduced to adsorb for 60 min. The temperature was then raised to 500 °C (the heating rate was 20 °C/min) to start desorption, and the thermal conductivity detector was used for detection. The NO-TPD profiles were processed with a Gaussian distribution function to calculate the activation energies for desorption of NO molecules on various catalysts, and the accuracy of the data is verified by simulation using the Arrhenius equation: (8) k = A e − E a R T where k is the reaction rate constant, A is the pre-exponential factor, also known as the Arrhenius constant, Ea is experimental activation energy, which can generally be regarded as a constant independent of temperature (kJ/mol), T is the absolute temperature (K), and R is the molar gas constant (kJ·mol−1·K−1). (9) q CoMoS = V × 22.4 1000 × 2 × C C o M o S where qCoMoS is the CoMoS active phase concentration (μmol/gCat), V is the total NO adsorption amount of each catalyst (cm3/gCat, STP). 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic activity was evaluated in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave with mechanical stirring, using decalin solution containing 2.0 wt.% DBT as model reactant. Typically, 30.0 g of reactant and 0.02 g of the Co-Mo sulfide were added into the reactor, followed by the H2 purge for three times to exchange the air inside the autoclave prior to the reaction. Each catalyst was tested under the same condition for three times to ensure the reliability. Then the reaction was carried out in H2 under the following conditions: the initial reaction pressure was 2.0 MPa at room temperature, the reaction temperature was 300 °C, the stirring speed was 600 r/min, and the reaction was carried out for 4 h. Finally, the liquid product was collected by centrifugation and analyzed on an Agilent 7890 GC-MS instrument equipped with HP-5MS column (30 m × 0.25 mm, 0.25 μm) and flame ionization detector (FID). The DBT conversion is used to evaluate the HDS activity of as-prepared catalysts, which can be calculated by the following equation: (11) x D B T ( % ) = C 0 − C t C 0 × 100 where xDBT is DBT conversion (%), C0 is the DBT content in the feedstock (wt.%) and Ct is the DBT content in the product (wt.%). The apparent reaction rate is calculated through the following equation [21]: (12) r = W m × t × x D B T where r is the apparent reaction rate (mol/(gcat·s)), W is the molar weight of the reactant (mol), m is catalyst weight (g), and t is reaction duration (s). The turnover frequency (TOF) of the catalysts is calculated by the following equation: (13) T O F = r q C o M o S where TOF is the turnover frequency of catalysts (s−1) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystalline structures Fig. 1 A shows the XRD pattern of Co-Mo oxide precursor prepared at 80 °C. Most of the diffraction peaks can be well assigned to the characteristic diffraction peaks of CoMoO4 phase (JCPDS No. 15-0493), while several weak diffraction peaks are attributed to CoMoO6·0.9H2O phase (JCPDS No. 14-0086). The CoMoO4 oxide can be directly synthesized by replacement reaction without heating treatment, which is consistent with the results in the previously reported literatures [19–21]. The XRD patterns of the sulfide catalysts are shown in Fig. 1B. It was found that most of the diffraction peaks of CoMoO4 disappeared after pre-sulfurized at 120 °C, indicating the transformation of oxide precursor into sulfide. However, the diffraction peaks of both Mo and Co sulfides are hard to be discerned. Some diffraction peaks of CoMoO4, such as the one assigned to (002) plane, are still existed. The intensity of the diffraction peaks of MoS2 (JCPDS No. 74-0932) and Co9S8 (JCPDS No. 86-2273) gradually strengthened with the increasing of pre-sulfurization temperature, suggesting the facilitated phase transformation from oxide to sulfide and the promoted growth of sulfide crystallites with the increasing of pre-sulfurization temperature [22]. 3.2 Morphology and structure analysis The morphologies of the samples were obtained by SEM, TEM and HRTEM analyses. Fig. 2 A is the SEM image of Co-Mo oxide precursor, showing rod-like morphology with nearly square cross-section, and the length and width of which are concentrated at 0.5∼1.5 μm and 100∼150 nm, respectively. The rod-like particle is not complete crystal, but a combination of smaller particles, as reported by Kianpour et al. [20]. There are two steps in the formation process of CoMoO4 rod-like particles, initial nucleating stage and growth stage. At the beginning, small crystallites are formed when the mixed Co-Mo solution supersaturated. Then large rod-like particles with uniform particle size are assembled spontaneously through prolonging the synthesis time. The inset HRTEM image of Fig. 2B shows well-resolved lattice planes of precursor. The interplanar spacing of 0.32 nm is very close to the (002) plane of CoMoO4 phase, suggesting the preferential growth along the direction parallel to the (001) plane. The precursor was transformed from oxide into sulfide after pre-sulfurization and activation processes, during which the morphology structure was markedly affected by the pre-sulfurization temperature. As shown in Fig. 2C, although the surface became rough, the rod-like shape of the particle was basically unchanged when pre-sulfurizedat 120 °C, and no distinguished hollow structure was observed inside the particle. As shown in Fig. 2D–F, the surface of particles became rougher, and the hollow structure gradually increased with the pre-sulfurization temperature. These changes indicate that higher pre-sulfurization temperature is favorable for the formation of sulfide particles with open-ended tube-like structures. The formation of hollow structure was also confirmed in the previous works, which could be attributed to the relative diffusion metal or sulfide ions and the etching effect of ethanol in pre-sulfurization agent [18,23–25]. During the sulfurization process, the precursor particles can be etched by ethanol. These exfoliated species are more easily to sulfurize than intact particles, which induces the precursors achieving a high sulfidation degree even at lower sulfurization temperatures (< 200 °C). Thus, the results illustrate that higher temperature can promote the diffusion effect of different ions, as well as the dissolving and etching properties of ethanol for Co-Mo oxide precursor. 3.3 Properties The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Co-Mo sulfide catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The small and narrow hysteresis loops of all the samples at higher relative pressure (> 0.8) are observed, indicating that the pore size is relatively large. While no distinct uptake at low relative pressure (< 0.1) are observed, suggesting the absence of micropores. Furthermore, all isotherms are of Type II, further verifying the presence of large mesopores and macropores [26]. All hysteresis loops are of Type H3, suggesting that the pores are formed by the aggregation or stacking of particles. The pore diameter of all catalysts is mainly distributed in the range of 10–120 nm and concentrated at 60 nm, which are shown in the inset of Fig. 3. In comparison, the catalyst Cat-160 has more macropores because of the high dV/dD value. Combining with the TEM analyses, it can be found that the large mesopores and macropores are mainly from the pores in the wall of tube-like particles and the inner pores of particles, respectively. It is also worth to note that the Cat-120catalyst has a considerable number of macropores, although these pores are not observed in TEM image of Fig. 2C. This suggests that many pores have been produced through dissolution and etching process with ethanol when the pre-sulfurization was conducted at 120 °C, however, the produced pores located on the surface of catalyst particles are not interconnected to form larger hollow structure, thus cannot be distinguished in the TEM image. The specific surface area (SSA), pore volume (PV), and average pore diameter (APD) of as-prepared catalysts are shown in Table 1 . It is found that the Cat-120 catalyst shows relatively high SSA and lower PV and APD. As illustrated in the TEM characterization, the high pre-sulfurization temperature is beneficial to the formation of hollow structures, leading to the increased PV and APD values of Cat-120, Cat-140 and Cat-160 catalysts. However, the PV and APD values decreased when further increasing the pre-sulfurization temperature to 180 °C, because the increasing pre-sulfurization temperature not only promoted the sulfurization degree of the precursor, but also enhanced the dissolving and etching capacity of ethanol for metal ions. These effects promote the construction of the porosity and inner space of catalysts, but may destroy the structure of rod-like particles at the same time. As a result, parts of the tube-like particles are further broken into small pieces, therefore, the hollow structure disappear. According to the results in Table 1, the suitable pre-sulfurization of the Co-Mo precursor is 160 °C to obtain the catalysts with more hollow structure, high SSA and PV. 3.4 Active phase composition and microstructure XPS analysis was applied to investigate the chemical state of Mo and Co species on the surface of various Co-Mo sulfide catalysts as shown in Fig. 4 . In Fig. 4A, the Mo 3d bands for all catalysts were deconvoluted into three peaks at the binding energy of 224.0-238.0 eV, which can be attributed in turn to MoS2 3d5/2, MoS2 3d3/2, and other molybdenum sulfide species (Mo+6/Mo+5). In Fig. 4B, all Co 2p3/2 bands were also deconvoluted into three peaks at the binding energy of 776.0-784.0 eV, which can be assigned to the Co2+ species, Co-Mo-S active phase and Co9S8, respectively. The Mo and Co spectra are both similar to the previously reported results in the literatures [27–29], indicating that the pre-sulfurization temperature will not affect the surface compositions of the sulfide catalysts although the relative content of different species exists difference. Moreover, Co2+ species were distinguished in the Co 2p spectra of all catalysts. This highly dispersed species are believed to be formed during the passivation process of fresh Co-Mo catalyst [30,31]. The Co2+ species were not detected by XRD technique, because only the near-surface of cobalt sulfide was partly oxidized. The atomic percentage of surface-active species were calculated from the XPS data and shown in Table 2 . It can be found that the concentrations of metal oxides gradually decreased while that of sulfides increased with the increasing of pre-sulfurization temperature, indicating that the higher temperature can improve the sulfurization of the precursors. Nevertheless, when the pre-sulfurization temperature further increased up to 180 °C, the concentration of CoMoS species decreased rapidly. Herein, the pre-sulfurization process can be deemed as a complex solvothermal process in the ethanol. Both sulfurization reaction and crystallite growth were occurred during this process, which was promoted by increasing the temperature simultaneously. As a result, the Co atoms preferred to form single Co9S8 phase rather than interact with MoS2 to form CoMoS species at higher temperature. Since Clausen et al. [32] discovered the CoMoS species on the surface of Co-Mo/alumina catalyst, it has been recognized as the main active species and shows a superior desulfurization activity in DBT conversion. Thus, the Cat-160 catalyst with more CoMoS species may possess more catalytic active sites and show higher activity. Both experimental results and theoretical calculation have verified that the microstructure or morphology of (Co)MoS2 crystallites, that is the length and stacking number of (Co)MoS2 slabs, play a key role in the reaction rate of DBT hydrodesulfurization and the selectivity of liquid products [33,34]. Thus, the slab length and stacking number for all catalysts were analyzed (see Figs. S1–S4) and the statistical results were shown in Fig. 5 . In terms of the slab length, the length decreases gradually with the increased pre-sulfurization temperature. The high pre-sulfurization temperature accelerated the dissolution of Co and Mo atoms, leading to the destruction of CoMoO4 crystal structure and the formation of smaller crystallites. As a result, the sulfide catalyst is composed of shorter (Co)MoS2 slabs. The shorter slabs lead to higher fraction of Mo atoms at corner sites. Recently, the DFT calculation [35] indicated that CUSs were more easily generated at the corner sites than the edge of (Co)MoS2 slabs, and the sulfur atoms in DBT preferred to be strongly adsorbed on the corner sites. Thus, increasing pre-sulfurization temperature may improve the catalytic desulfurization activity of the catalyst. Compared to the slab length, the stacking number was not significantly affected by the pre-sulfurization temperature, and mainly distributed at 3-5 layers for all catalysts as observed in Fig. 5B. Topsøe [36] found that the Co-Mo-S phase on the surface of supported Co-Mo catalysts may be of either Type I (monolayered structure) or Type II (multilayered structure), and the latter often shows better catalytic property due to the high exposure of active sites and sulfurization extent. Since the as-prepared catalyst is unsupported and without the interaction between metal and support, monolayered (Co)MoS2 slab is not found, which indicates that the (Co)MoS2 slabs of all catalysts show the structure of Type II with high active. Based on the statistical results, the average length and average stacking number of (Co)MoS2 slabs as well as the distribution of Mo atoms were calculated, as show in Table 3 . Because of the shortest average length, the ratio of fc /fe for the Cat-160catalyst is the highest, suggesting that there are relatively more Mo atoms located at the corner sites of (Co)MoS2 slabs. Although the calculation of fe or fc did not take into account the stacking number, this parameter, especially the number of accessible corner sites, can actually affect the number of active sites. Thus, the ratio of N A/L A was calculated to describe the effect of the morphology of (Co)MoS2 slabs on the number of surface-active sites. The higher ratio of N A/L A means more Mo atoms at the corner sites, leading to the higher catalytic desulfurization activity of the Cat-160 catalyst. The HDS reaction activity of Co-Mo transition metal sulfide catalysts mainly comes from the CoMoS active phase, so determining the content of the CoMoS active phase in the catalyst (especially the catalyst that may contain multiple active phases, such as Co9S8, unpromoted and Co-promoted MoS2) has intuitive guiding significance for improving the catalytic activity of the catalyst [37,38]. Because of its relatively high selectivity and adsorption strength, NO molecules are often used as probe molecules to characterize hydrogenation catalysts [39], especially for transition metal sulfide HDS catalysts, since NO molecules are only adsorbed on the active sites with catalytic activity [40]. NO is a molecule with an odd number of electrons, two NO molecules form dinitrosyl species [41–43] or dimer species [44,45] through the interaction between unpaired electrons and then stably adsorb on the adsorbate surface, which means that one active site can adsorb two NO molecules [37–39]. Generally, TPD [46] and IR technology [43,47,48] are used to characterize the adsorption behavior of NO molecules to detect the active sites of HDS catalysts. Due to lower light transmittance of sulfide catalysts, NO-TPD was used instead of NO-IR in this work. The NO-TPD profiles of various Co-Mo sulfide catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 A. All of them have a single NO desorption peak between 50 and 250 °C, and the peak areas of Cat-140 and Cat-160 are larger than those of Cat-120 and Cat-180, this may be because the (Co)MoS2 slabs with high stacking layers of Cat-140 and Cat-160 provide more adsorption sites for NO molecules. The information obtained by TPD was simulated by using the Arrhenius equation (Fig. 6B). The desorption activation energy was roughly distributed in the range of 95–108 kJ/mol (Table 4 ), indicating that the NO molecules desorbed after 50 °C are attributed to chemisorption of NO molecules. The total amount of NO molecule desorption (STP) of the catalysts at different sulfurization temperatures is shown in Table 4. The number of active sites (including Co9S8, unpromoted and Co-promoted MoS2) of the catalyst can be directly calculated from the amount of desorbed NO molecules (using a 2:1 stoichiometry of NO molecules and active sites) [37–39]. The number of active sites of the catalysts increases first and then decreases with the increase of sulfurization temperature. Combining with the results in Table 2, the absolute content of the CoMoS phase was calculated, showing a similar trend of first increasing and then decreasing, in which Cat-160 has the most CoMoS active phase. 3.5 HDS activity tests The reaction results of DBT hydrodesulfurization over the four catalysts are shown in Table 5 and Fig. S5. The activity of the catalysts firstly increases and then decreases with the increasing of pre-sulfurization temperature. Although the parallel tests caused slight change in DBT conversion for each catalyst, the activity tendency was not affected markedly. The Cat-160 exhibits the highest conversion and reaction rate while Cat-180 exhibits the lowest one, as expected. Combining with the characterizations of XPS and NO-TPD, the catalytic activity highly depends on the concentration and number of CoMoS species (Fig. S6), which confirms that the highly active sites that take part in DBT conversion are mainly supplied by CoMoS species, although other active species exist as well, such as Co9S8 and MoS2. Four chemicals, including tetrahydrodibenzothiophene (THDBT), biphenyl (BP), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) and bicyclohexyl (BCH), were detected in the liquid products for all catalysts. Among them, THDBT, CHB and BCH are produced through hydrogenation route (HYD) while BP is produced through direct desulfurization route (DDS). Because of the low conversions, isomerized product such as benzyl cyclopentane was not detected. Daage and Chianelli [49] found that the hydrogenation ability of MoS2 slabs was directly dependent on the stacking degree, not related to the slab length along the basal direction. The yield of the hydrogenated products for the Cat-160 is higher due to the higher stacking number. Comparing with those hydrogenated products, the yield of BP is much higher, suggesting that the direct desulfurization route is predominant. The DFT calculation from electronic effect confirms that the promotion effect of Co is attributed to the electrons transferred from Co to MoS2. This electron donation can weaken the Mo-S bond strength to an optimal value for enhancing the C-S bond cleavage rate to promote the direct desulfurization [50]. Although BP is the main product for all catalysts, the yield is also greatly affected by the microstructures of active species. For catalysts Cat-120, Cat-140, and Cat-160, the ratio of both fc /fe and N A/L A increase in turn, leading to the increasing number of corner sites. Zhang et al. [35,51] recently investigated the effect of the corner sites of (Co)MoS2 slabs on the DBT conversion by DFT calculations, demonstrating that compared to the edge sites, the corner sites are more favorable to generate sulfur vacancies during HDS reaction because of lower formation energy, and those vacancies at the corner sites can reduce the reaction barrier of C-S bond scission and consequently accelerate the direct desulfurization route, thus leading to the highest yield of BP for Cat-160. Because of the lower concentration of CoMoS species, more corner sites of the catalyst Cat-180 may locate at the MoS2 slabs that not promoted by Co atoms. These corner sites possess lower activities than that of Co-promoted MoS2 slabs, such that the Cat-180 catalyst shows the lowest catalytic desulfurization activity even though it has higher fc /fe and N A/L A ratios than Cat-120 and Cat-140. In addition, the tube-like unsupported Co-Mo catalyst demonstrated higher HDS activity by comparison with the published results (Table S1). It should be noted that the reaction temperature and H2 pressure of the tube-like Co-Mo unsupported catalyst are lower than the published results. This means that the tube-like Co-Mo unsupported catalyst can exhibit higher HDS activity under the same reaction conditions. In addition to the temperature, the pre-sulfurization time can also affect the activity of the catalyst. As mentioned above, the catalyst prepared by the pre-sulfurization of precursor at 160 °C exhibited higher desulfurization activity. Thus, various catalysts were prepared by pre-sulfurizing the precursors at 160 °C for different time, and their catalytic activities were evaluated to investigate the effects of the pre-sulfurization time. As illustrated in Table 6 and Fig. S7, the reaction rate increases rapidly as the pre-sulfurization time is prolonged from 2 h to 6 h, and then gradually plateau from 6 h to 8 h. This suggests that the longer pre-sulfurization time is favorable to obtain higher active catalyst, but if the catalyst has been well sulfurized, further prolonging the time cannot enhance the activity remarkably. The yields of the liquid products show that BP is still the main product, and the direct desulfurization route is predominant. The pre-sulfurization time only affects the catalytic activity on DBT conversion, not the reaction route and product selectivity. 4 Conclusions In this work, porous tube-like Co-Mo sulfide particles were simply prepared through co-precipitation and low-temperature pre-sulfurization. The pre-sulfurization temperature is a key factor for the catalyst in the desulfurization activity. Within a certain range, a higher pre-sulfurization temperature can promote the diffusion effect of active metal ions as well as the dissolution and etching capacity of ethanol for the Co-Mo oxide precursor, which is beneficial to the formation of hollow structure with relatively large specific surface area. In addition, the higher temperature can promote the sulfurization of CoMoO4 precursor and the formation of Type II CoMoS active slabs with shorter length and higher stacking number, resulting more Mo atoms at the corner sites. Because of the relatively larger pore volume, high surface concentration of CoMoS species, and more corner sites, the Cat-160 shows higher DBT reaction rate and BP yield than other catalysts. Moreover, when the pre-sulfurization temperature is specified, prolonging pre-sulfurization time can also improve the catalytic desulfurization activity of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A Co-Mo sulfide catalyst with tube-like structure was prepared through a low-temperature pre-sulfurization process using rod-like CoMoO4 as the precursor. The pre-sulfurization temperature greatly affected the total pore volume, the concentration of CoMoS species, the microstructure of (Co)MoS2 slabs and the catalytic desulfurization activity. The increased temperature can promote the formation of hollow structure and the sulfurization degree of the precursor. It was found that the excessive temperature induced the Co atoms to form more isolated Co9S8 species, hindering the formation of highly active CoMoS species. Therefore, appropriate temperature is more favorable to form the (Co)MoS2 slabs with shorter length and higher stacking number, leading to more coordinatively unsaturated sites, especially the corner sites. According to the results of hydrodesulfurization reaction, the reaction rate of dibenzothiophene and the yields of liquid products are highly depended on the number of surface-active sites, which are mainly originated from the Type II CoMoS species. Moreover, the extended pre-sulfurization time can further improve the catalytic desulfurization activity of the catalyst at an appropriate pre-sulfurization temperature.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of temperature and time on the facile low-temperature pre-sulfurization of tube-like unsupported Co-Mo catalysts for hydrodesulfurization
